entries.text: Do you take pride in your craft and want to have fun() at the same time? Are you a geek? Join the team of iwantmyname from anywhere.
entries.title: Back-End Blacksmith

entries.text: Joel Berger announces the new release of PDL, the Perl Data Language. Now with 64bit support!
entries.title: PDL 2.007 Released!

entries.text: Haico Kuut explains Booking.com's strategy to nurture and retain their talent pool.
entries.title: How we do talent development in Booking.com IT

entries.text: Shinji Tanaka benchmarked how REST API servers written in Go, Perl and Ruby perform. The results are quite interesting: Go wins, but Perl is pleasantly not very far behind, both leaving Ruby somewhat far behind.
entries.title: The Benchmark with Go REST API Server

entries.text: Dancer's all-the-app-in-a-single-pm is terrific for small applications. But that simplicity might not cut it once a project has grown past a certain size.  Patrick Fraley shows us how he organizes the code of such bigger applications to keep everything under control.
entries.title: Structuring larger Dancer Applications

entries.text: The Perl testing culture. Is it good? You betcha. Is it perfect? Not even remotely close. Ovid brings up this laundry list of the typical sins we commit in our test suites, and how we can, and should improve on it.
entries.title: The Problem With Perl Testing

entries.text: Real life has swiss army knives and duct tape, the Unix environment has Perl and cron.  David Farrell offers a nice little tutorial on how to make those two fundamental sysadmin tools play well together.
entries.title: How to schedule Perl scripts using cron

entries.text: OAuth. Not the easiest thing to grok, but if one wants to work with web services nowadays, it's pretty hard to ignore. Ricardo Signes shares with us small scripts that perform the authentication dance with with Instapaper's and Withings's APIs.
entries.title: writing OAuthy code

entries.text: Sometimes it's a good exercise to port an application from framework A to framework B, just so see how the two compare. That's exactly what Joel Berger did here, for his own edification, and ours.
entries.title: Some code ports to Mojolicious, just for fun.

entries.text: Quick, what are the -M, -A and -C file tests doing in Perl? Don't remember? Well, don't worry: Sebastian reminds us of those little known but handy tests.
entries.title: Perl -M-A-C tests

entries.text: Email::Valid is a handy module, but it also has.. surprising edges, as the Perl Hacker Painter found out.
entries.title: Email::Valid Peculiarities

entries.text: Halloween is approaching, and in that spirit Ovid shares with us the terrifying tale of how he battled an ancient evil, born of an Age all but forgotten.
entries.title: Fighting a 30-year-old software bug

entries.text: Two reasons to rejoice. Upasana announces that Moose's exceptions are now lovingly structured, and gives us a rather impressive summary of what she learned during her internship for Moose as part of the GNOME Outreach Program for Women.
entries.title: Yay! Moose is free from stringy exceptions!

entries.text: fREW presents here his latest work-in-progress, a module that auto-detect details of the database a DBIx::Class handler points to.
entries.title: DBIx::Introspector

entries.text: Shawn Moore was the dark Sith master to Upasana's Padawanernship. He gives us the tale of her exceptional rise to power, and an inkling of the joy and work that goes into mentoring.
entries.title: Structured Exceptions in Moose Mentorship

entries.text: David Oswald gives a primer on some of the basic Perl's functions to deal with arrays, both from the core (grep, map, sort) and beyond (first, reduce, any, all, pairwise, etc).
entries.title: Perl's Functional Functions

entries.text: by Moritz Lenz
entries.title: A small regex optimization for NQP and Rakudo

entries.text: November 2-3, 2013, Salzburg, Austria
entries.title: Austrian Perl Workshop

entries.text: November 15-16, 2013, Curitiba, PR, Brazil
entries.title: YAPC::Brazil 2013

entries.text: November 23, 2013, Copenhagen, Denmark
entries.title: Nordic Perl Workshop 2013

entries.text: Saturday 30th November 2013 at Westminster University
entries.title: London Perl Workshop (LPW 2013)

chapters.title: Events

header: With Perl, it doesn't matter how long you've been programming or how well you know the language: there's always room for surprises. Whether it's the eccentric corner-case behavior of an otherwise trustworthy module, an intriguing new experiments born of a brilliant mind, or performance results that beats expectations, you can bet that there's at least one link below that will make you go "oh, really?". "Oh, really?", I hear the skeptics in the room say. To which I confidently reply: "Oooh yes. Really." ~ `/anick
subject: Peculiar Modules, Odd Behaviors and Surprising Finds
